differences.concept_a_point: The chemical reaction inside the primary cell is irreversible
differences.concept_b_point: The chemical reaction inside the secondary cell is reversible

differences.concept_a_point: It cannot be recharged after use
differences.concept_b_point: It can be recharged and reused

differences.concept_a_point: Used in small devices such as torches, toys, radios, bicycles and small tape recorders
differences.concept_b_point: Used in mobile phones, cameras, computers and emergency lights

differences.concept_a_point: Simple voltaic cell, Daniel cell, Leclanche cell and dry cell
differences.concept_b_point: Lead accumulator, Edison accumulator and nickel-iron accumulator

differences.concept_a_point: There is a sharing of voltage (potential difference) among appliances
differences.concept_b_point: Each appliance gets the original voltage

differences.concept_a_point: All appliances work simultaneously
differences.concept_b_point: All appliances work independently

differences.concept_a_point: If any appliance gets damaged, remaining appliances also stop working because circuit gets broken
differences.concept_b_point: If any appliance gets damaged, remaining ones continue to work as all appliances work independently

differences.concept_a_point: Not used in household wiring
differences.concept_b_point: Used in household wiring system with separate switches for each appliance

differences.concept_a_point: Substances which allow electric current to flow through them easily
differences.concept_b_point: Substances which do not allow electric current to flow through them

differences.concept_a_point: All metals such as copper, silver, nickel, aluminium, iron and steel
differences.concept_b_point: Cotton, rubber, paper, glass, ceramics, plastic, wood

differences.concept_a_point: Impure water is a conductor
differences.concept_b_point: Pure water is an insulator

differences.concept_a_point: Used as core of electric wires (e.g., copper)
differences.concept_b_point: Used to cover electric wires (e.g., plastic) to make them safe

differences.concept_a_point: A circuit in which no electric current flows
differences.concept_b_point: A circuit in which electric current flows

differences.concept_a_point: Occurs when the switch is off
differences.concept_b_point: Occurs when the switch is on

differences.concept_a_point: Circuit is incomplete - broken at some point
differences.concept_b_point: Circuit is complete - provides continuous path

differences.concept_a_point: Bulb does not glow
differences.concept_b_point: Bulb glows

differences.concept_a_point: Flows from positive terminal to negative terminal of battery
differences.concept_b_point: Flows from negative terminal to positive terminal (region of excess to deficit)

differences.concept_a_point: Based on convention (established practice) before electrons were discovered
differences.concept_b_point: Based on actual movement of electrons

differences.concept_a_point: Direction is opposite to electron flow
differences.concept_b_point: Direction is opposite to conventional current

differences.concept_a_point: Contains a wire that melts and breaks the circuit when current exceeds permissible value
differences.concept_b_point: An automatically operated safety device that breaks the circuit in case of overload or short circuit

differences.concept_a_point: Needs to be replaced every time there is an overflow of current
differences.concept_b_point: Can be reset manually or automatically to restore electricity

differences.concept_a_point: Less sensitive to current changes
differences.concept_b_point: More sensitive to current - can detect even a slight fluctuation in voltage and interrupt circuit current fast

questions.source_section: Prepping for PISA - Fuse vs MCB

differences.concept_a_point: A single unit that converts chemical energy into electrical energy
differences.concept_b_point: A combination of two or more cells connected in series

differences.concept_a_point: Provides a small amount of electricity
differences.concept_b_point: Provides more electrical energy for devices requiring higher power

differences.concept_a_point: Used in small devices like calculators, watches, TV remotes
differences.concept_b_point: Used in vehicles like cars and trucks, and in emergency lights

differences.concept_a_point: Acts as an insulator - does not conduct electricity
differences.concept_b_point: Acts as a conductor - allows electricity to flow

differences.concept_a_point: Has very few ions to carry electric current
differences.concept_b_point: Contains dissolved salts and minerals that provide ions to carry current

differences.concept_a_point: Safe to use near electrical appliances
differences.concept_b_point: Dangerous - can cause electric shock if used near electrical appliances

differences.concept_a_point: Positive electrode
differences.concept_b_point: Negative electrode

differences.concept_a_point: Carbon rod with brass cap acts as anode
differences.concept_b_point: Zinc container acts as cathode

differences.concept_a_point: Conventional current enters the device through anode
differences.concept_b_point: Conventional current leaves the device through cathode

differences.concept_a_point: Converts mechanical energy into electrical energy
differences.concept_b_point: Converts electrical energy into mechanical energy

differences.concept_a_point: A conductor (copper wire) is rotated in a magnetic field to produce current
differences.concept_b_point: Current through a conductor in magnetic field produces rotation

differences.concept_a_point: Dynamos in power stations, bicycle dynamo
differences.concept_b_point: Electric fans, washing machines, electric vehicles

differences.concept_a_point: Uses the energy of flowing water to rotate turbines
differences.concept_b_point: Uses fossil fuels (coal, diesel, natural gas) to produce steam which rotates turbines

differences.concept_a_point: Clean energy - no pollution from burning fuel
differences.concept_b_point: Produces pollution from burning fossil fuels

differences.concept_a_point: Requires continuous flow of water - depends on rainfall/dams
differences.concept_b_point: Requires continuous supply of fossil fuels which are non-renewable

differences.concept_a_point: Helps in making and breaking of the circuit - quick on/off operation
differences.concept_b_point: Helps in keeping a circuit open or closed for longer duration

differences.concept_a_point: Used for regular on/off operation of appliances
differences.concept_b_point: Used for extended periods of circuit control

differences.concept_a_point: Usually mounted on walls or on appliances
differences.concept_b_point: Often used in experimental circuits and laboratories
